answers.answer: They have blood tests available for both ALS and MS.  Ask your doctor for them if you're concerned - if the doc is any good at all, she will allow that.  Also, ask about having an EMG, which is a test of the muscles.  It's a bit uncomfortable but by no means painful.

There is no 1 bloodtest for ALS/MS. Most people are Dx'd byruling out a series of bloodtests/brain & spine mri's. Eventhen, when you are at ofc., the Dr. can watch/listen to you todecide what next. You articulate well & your thoughts readclear. It would help you to know Dr's opinion & if mri wouldhelp Dx. Get copies for a hm-health-file on any tests. It may bea disk/nerve/RLS? I'd ask for a brain mri & see what response is. May need a neurologist. Gd-luck.
A related discussion, Bubbling calves, bubbling legs was started.

question: Hello.  About a month ago, my legs startless feeling strange...like they "weren't working".  Felt like I was walking strange.  (At times, would get muscle soreness for no reason)  About a week ago, I woke up with foot muscle spasms...and since then, have had a constant bubbly feeling all over calves (and in front), sometimes in thighs, and a pins & needles/vibrating feeling all over both feet.  This is constant, in both legs and both feet, although it bothers me most when sitting or lying down.  I still feel like I walk funny.  It's like my legs and feet are constantly being "shocked".  As millions of others, I am so worried about ALS and MS.  My glucose level today was 97, so doctor doesn't suspect diabetes.  Yet, she didn't seem concerned about this sudden onset of muscle twitching/vibrating.  Does this sound to you like ALS?  Thank you for your time.  Holly
title: Calves
